Rome Style Hotel
9.1 Exceptional
Based on 29 reviews

Hotel Palazzo Manfredi – Relais & Chateaux
9.1 Exceptional
Based on 40 reviews

I travel extensively & have to say I have a preference for Relais Chateau properties. This hotel is very well positioned & one of the best locations in Rome.

The apartments are beautifully decorated & spacious & we stayed in the Marcus Aurelius suite. The real differences of this hotel is the staff, Christine at the front desk was incredible in how she accommodated every need with a smile. She helped from our awkward arrival from the airport with a taxi driver who would only take cash at 11pm (we had not had the chance to exchange), to booking great restaurants & priority tours to the best attractions. I have visited Rome before & it is a city where you really benefit from expert suggestions. We also met the general manager Bruno who made clear that nothing short of perfection was acceptable & Christine & him get pretty close to this goal. Our one mistake was that we did not stay longer - Thank You Christine & Bruno.

Show more
Saul , United Kingdom
Twenty One Hotel
8 Very good
Based on 159 reviews

The hotel is centrally located, with many tourist spots within walking distance. The hotel is very nicely presented, and is reasonably priced for it's location.

The restaurant and room service menus are incredible. We were disappointed by a few things though: 1) Even though we'd specified on the booking that we were a couple and the hotel seems to market itself towards couples, our double room consisted of two single beds pushed together. When we asked at reception if it was possible to change these for a single large mattress, we were told that the hotel doesn't possess any double mattresses, and their solution was to stuff extra blankets between the two beds. We spent the entire weekend unable to get a good night's sleep, and suffering from back pain. 2) Whilst the wifi works fast and reliably in the reception/lobby and restaurant, it was virtually impossible to collect so much as an email from the room, even though all our devices showed a full signal. We ended up having to resort to data roaming on our phones, which obviously incurred additional cost.

Show more
Christopher , United Kingdom
NH Collection Palazzo Cinquecento
9 Excellent
Based on 73 reviews

This hotel was incredibly disappointing. We requested one queen bed. Upon check-in, we had two twin beds.

We asked to change and the second room was crawling with ants. They were even in the bed. The bathroom was filthy with something sticky spilled on the floor and not cleaned. We moved back tot he first room. The rooms were stifling hot. You could not turn down the air below 22 degrees C without calling the front desk where the air is controlled. We awoke in the middle of the night every night and could not go back to sleep because the room was hot. When I inquired about this, I was told that they turn it off at night and that we should call the front desk if we wanted it back on - extremely inconvenient. We were never cool no matter what the thermostat said. In addition, the breakfast buffet is 20 Euros if you purchase it upon check-in, 26 if you purchase it after. Definitely not worth the money - incredibly overpriced. Don't bother with it. You can go down the street and get an omelet for 6 euros. After traveling three weeks in Europe, this was our last stop. We had NO complaints whatsoever at the other 7 hotels that we stayed in. This hotel was awful at any price.

Show more
Cindy , United States
A.Roma Lifestyle Hotel
8.8 Excellent
Based on 107 reviews

This hotel is simply brilliant. It's a little way out of the city centre but this is no problem at all.

..in fact, it's probably better than trying to stay right in the centre. Especially if you're driving. This hotel has ample free parking and they provide a regular shuttle into the city centre for €2.00. Even if you end up taking a taxi, a trip to the city centre is only €15.00. The staff are amazingly polite, friendly and helpful. A wonderful welcome after a long drive. The hotel isn't much to look at from the outside but the inside is great. Very modern and cool. The rooms are plenty big enough and well appointed. Not much to see out of the windows but it doesn't matter. The minibar has free water and soft drinks, which I thought was a nice touch. I was a little shocked to see that every room service order has a €15.00 surcharge (on top of the usual expensive room service prices) but then they redeemed themselves enormously when I found a little flyer saying that you could have a pizza, an arancini and a soft drink delivered right to your room (made in the restaurant downstairs) for only €10.00 (with no surcharge). The breakfast is a little odd. The food is fine and the coffee is good but everything is spread out so you end up spending about 15 minutes walking all over the restaurant to get your coffee, water, juice, food, etc. Once you've got everything you need though, the breakfast is great. They even have a take away coffee machine so that you can take one back to your room. The hidden gem of this hotel is the pool and spa. We booked the hotel mainly for sightseeing so we didn't really pay attention to the spa. On the day of checkout however, after a long day's sightseeing the day before, we thought we'd check out the pool. It's fantastic! You walk through the very modern and expansive spa to the outdoor pool which is beautiful. Set in the hotel gardens which have been very well maintained. There's also an indoor pool if you don't fancy going outside.

Show more
Richard , United Kingdom
FH Grand Hotel Palatino
8.3 Excellent
Based on 144 reviews

The hotel is on a main road with lots of restaurants, 2min from Cavour station, which is one station away from Termini station - Rome's regional station which you can get to from the airport via bus or train.

Rooms are large and comfortable. Free wifi is only in the lobby. At night, I called reception to ask for a kettle to boil hot water (no hotels in Italy have kettles in the room). The man on duty dismissively told me to call the bar instead, which I did but no one picked up so I called reception again - he said the staff at bar are probably busy and told me to call the bar again later. I got very fed up with his irresponsible attitude and requested that he arrange it for me instead, he answered with 'Okay, thank you' and hung up, leaving me unsure if he was going to do it or not. After 20+min, no one came and I still could not call through to the bar, so I called reception again and he agreed to chase up the bar staff. A flask of hot water arrived shortly after this (finally). The next morning, I had to deal with another lady at reception with terrible attitude, but there was also an older man at reception who was lovely, polite and so helpful - our tour company had given us the wrong starting hotel information and he helped us call around to find out where we needed to be.

Show more
Alice , Australia
VOI Donna Camilla Savelli Hotel
9 Excellent
Based on 134 reviews

After having a fantastic stay at Donna Camilla Savelli last September, we returned for our honeymoon in October this year.

On checking in we were taken to our room/small kennel which had the television falling off the wall. I organised to move to a larger room which we were happier with especially after seeing the television was still on the wall, although the leaking bath made for a slippery marble floor. I immediately requested this be repaired although this never occured over our 3 night stay. After checking in to the second, larger room, I received a call from reception saying we needed to pay an extra 50 as when we booked the double room online, we only listed one guest. We were told extra lotions and soaps were required for an extra person so we must pay accordingly.. Breakfast time and the scrambled eggs are swimming in juice/water as was the bacon. I did ask for these to be refreshed but the staff turned their nose up at me, as did the front office Manager when I showed him the 'quality' of his breakfast buffet. I asked the Manager for an ommlette and was told that would be extra.. wifi in public areas? ignorant staff, $28 in house movies?! NEVER AGAIN..

Show more
Andrew , Australia
Royal Court Hotel
8.1 Excellent
Based on 372 reviews

We arrived in Rome on Wednesday 25th May for my partners birthday, we got to the room and I was extremely disappointed, it was tiny, dark and very old fashioned, not what some of the pictures looked like so not really what I was expecting, that said I went to the front desk and told the chap there I wasn't happy as it was booked as a SUPRISE for my partners birthday, I asked if there was another room he could move us too.

. He said he will have a look and he did. He found us a fantastic room (the secret room) with roof top terrace, we both extremely enjoyed our time at the royal court hotel after. The room was immaculate and bathroom too!! The shower was terrible, I had to sort it out very time I went in and it took me about 20 minutes each time to get the water hot enough to stand in.. (Just) There wasn't a restaurant but there were so many to choose from in the centre of Rome so it wasn't to disappointing.. Would I go back to the same hotel?? I wouldn't completely write it off!! I would like to thank the man who moved our rooms for us he was really kind and helpful!! Tip: take summer clothes in May it gets to 30 degrees- ✌️ Enjoy your holiday!!!

Show more
Kayleigh , United Kingdom
Augusta Lucilla Palace Hotel
8.2 Excellent
Based on 680 reviews

We stayed here during the very dead period of Aug 14 to Aug 17, since there weren't too many sights to see and explore in Rome we found ourselves hovering about the hotel she it got too hot to be out in the day.

It's a 7 min walk from the termini at a good pace and about 15 to 20 min to all other sights of interest in Rome, if you aren't a walker then longer. There isn't much to do see or do around the neighbourhood and it gets very dead in the evenings. The hotel itself was satisfactory, the highlight of our stay was the excellent service at the front desk. Breakfast was satisfactory. It's a very cramped for space kind of place the room we stayed in was tiny, the breakfast area downstairs also felt very crowded, it could get a little claustrophobic if you spent more than a few hours in the room. Definitely the kind of place if you plan on being out and about the whole day and just need a space to park luggage and get to bed in the evening. Full disclosure I live and work in SE Asia and I am used to much more space from hotels!

Show more
Sunil , India
Hotel Giolli Nazionale
7.7 Very good
Based on 70 reviews

The location was great. I could walk everywhere. However, once I got to my room, I found it so small that I could not open my (carry on size) luggage and get into the bathroom or out of the room.

It was so narrow, I was so claustrophobic, and I've stayed in small rooms before. Its really annoying to have to pack up my suitcase just to use the restroom. The staff was nice enough but don't ask them about any suggestions for things to do or anything of that sorts. I asked about a food tour and I was told "i don't know," and then he walked away. Hmm... ok, aren't you in hospitality? The breakfast was decent. Basic croissant and coffee, cheese, and cereal kind of thing. The space was clean besides my bed. The sheets were dirty and I called to have them cleaned. The guy seemed super annoyed and didn't want to change the pillow cases as well. Sorry to trouble you for wanting clean sheets that didn't have dirt and hair on them. I wouldn't stay again. You could find somewhere with a bigger room in the location for same or less.

Show more
Lauren , United States
Quirinale Hotel
8.2 Excellent
Based on 301 reviews

my husband and i returned to this hotel for our 10th wedding anniversary having stayed here for 4 nights on our honeymoon.

we were not let down. we opted for a superior room which is a great size and has beautiful antique furniture although with a lcd tv! on unpacking our cases, a bottle of chilled prosecco was delivered to our room - lovely gesture! the reception area is large and also full of antique furniture (a lovely place to chill out after touring the city). the restaurant is situated within an internal courtyard/garden which is simply divine -very relaxing and calm despite being so close to the city centre. a full choice of breakfast is available - from cereal, to fruit, cakes, cooked - no complaints. we dined in the restaurant for dinner one night and was the best meal of our stay (20% discount for hotel guests) and the service is impeccable. the hotel also has 2 computers were internet access is free alternatively wifi available free of charge. there is also a very small gym - never saw it used. the location of the hotel is ideal - approx 5-10 mins walk from the main train station termini - walking distance to all major sights - trevi fountain, spanish steps, colosseum. the metro is within 2 mins walk of the hotel (republica) which we used to visit the vatican (only 1 euro per journey and saved us 2.2 mile walk!). i would definitely return to this hotel again. great value for money - (we paid for 4 nights), beautiful surroundings, decor and quality service.

Show more
James , United Kingdom
Bettoja Mediterraneo Hotel
8 Very good
Based on 314 reviews

Check-in was pleasant. Originally offered a 6th floor room facing a small street, but after I mentioned my requests at booking time for an 8th floor room they offered me a viewing of both the 6th and 8th floor rooms.

The 8th floor room had large french windows with a bit of a view of roof tops, so we took that. Room size was large with broad corridors and lobby on each floor for a European hotel. It got pretty warm during the daytime in the room with the sun coming in the morning thru the french windows, but we were mostly out during daytime. My wife felt this was somewhat of an issue, although by midnight it was cool enough to need sheets to cover ourselved during sleep. The cot supplied for our 21 month old boy was a bit quaint and small with metal railings without padding, fortunately he didnt bang his head on it during the stay! The breakfast was average with good cappucino out of a machine being the highlight. Breakfast room was a very pleasant traditionally done up place with a lot of character, so were the lobby areas on the ground floor with a touch of grandness. Staff in the breakfast room were always smiley and friendly; at reception were always polite and answered questions reasonably clearly in English although not always smiley. Highlight was piedmont style beef stew with potatoes on the roof top restaurant with view of the city on our first night - a touch on the expensive side, but was delicious. Another highlight was the room cleaning service, which was excellent. Main negative was the city tax at the end of the stay: €30 was charged - we were not made aware of this by Agoda as the email implied no further charges from the hotel, at least I did not notice it while booking and this was not in the confirmatory email.

Show more
Sreekanth , United Kingdom
Hotel Diana Roof Garden
7.8 Very good
Based on 157 reviews

Hotel Diana Roma Rooftop Garden is THE BEST hotel, ever. When I first arrived in Rome, this is the first hotel which I stayed in, for 4 nights.

I wanted to extend my stay here, but they were fully-booked so I had to leave. The views from the rooftop garden of this hotel are simply breathtaking. And that makes up for the not-so-impressive views from some of the bedroom windows. Who cares when you can go up to the rooftop and look over Rome, anyway? The flowers on the rooftop garden smell like perfume. The first time I walked up there, I wondered who's expensive perfume was filling up the environment. Then I realized it was the beautiful flowers! There is a viewing "tower" in the garden which you can climb up (a spiral staircase) and look over the rooftops of Rome! It's beautiful! Belissima! The staff of this hotel has become like my family, really. If you strike up a conversation with any of the staff working on the rooftop garden, you will quickly find a new family member! I love all the staff at Hotel Diana Roma so much, that I honestly missed everyone, when I left! And that's why I wanted to extend, in the first place! For my last days in Italy, I came back to Rome and stayed here again. I got to say goodbye to everyone, and I'm so happy that I did! The rooms are of excellent standard, and you can connect your laptop to the cable wire of the t.v. and you can use their internet connection from there, or if you don't have a laptop, you can use your t.v. to connect to the internet. Flat-screen t.v. You can figure out how to do everything by taking a look at the remote control. The buffet breakfast is a real treat, and all throughout the day you can order food and wine that you like. At nighttime, seagulls float over the rooftop garden like white paper planes with bells attached to them. It's beautiful. A beautiful experience. 100%.

Show more
Charity , United States
Rome Times Hotel
8.9 Excellent
Based on 256 reviews

I stayed at the Rome Times and it exceeded my expectation. Designer rooms with king beds and fresh bed sheets.

A 'rain' shower plus small hand shower in the bathroom. Breakfast was offered on a self serve basis and included bacon and eggs, continental breads and cheeses, cereals plus such a wide selection of other items. Loved the vanilla croissants! After a day sightseeing, it was good to return to my air conditioned room. To ensure a good night's sleep, the rooms are double glazed but the area around the hotel is not at all noisy. The roof garden is just lovely and the staff are friendly. The Rome Times is situated along a small street but is close enough to walk to the Coliseum plus other attractions. There is a small supermarket across the road and a great ice cream shop down the way. The Rome Times and its surroundings are very safe at night. If I do visit Rome again then I will book the Rome Times.

Show more
Iris , United Kingdom
Radisson Blu es. Hotel Rome
7.1 Very good
Based on 494 reviews

The hotel may not be located in the greatest part of the city but it is a very central location with the the train station to the airport across the road from the hotel.

I had booked a junior suite for my stay which was satisfactory, although the floor was neither carpet nor wooden flooring but a strange black plastic material which was the softest thing I had ever walked on. The room was clean, bathroom and tub were amazing, view not so and neither was the noise at 6am from the restaurants and bars on the neighbouring streets all having their bins collected. Breakfast was also served as a buffet style as I have found in other Radisson hotels but the restaurant in which it is served cannot be matches by their other chains, top floor overlooking the city of Rome with the rooftop pool teasing you to take a dip, its a shame the temperature did not permit but it was great non the less. All of the staff I came across were friendly and polite, from reception to room service and restaurant to housekeeping. All greeted me in Italian and politely smiled as I attempted to also speak in their mother tongue. If you cannot speak Italian like myself then fear not as the vast majority of the staff on site do, however I did always try and speak in Italian but would be given my response in English, I think this again was their polite way of saying my Italian is quite up to par. I had gone to Rome with my girlfriend of 6 years to finally propose and on the second day of being here the occasion must have got to me as I requested a room upgrade from reception. Note online bookings only show the junior suite but their is also a master and the presidential suite. 1 of the 2 presidential suites were available and I duly asked to view the room which to describe is simply amazing. A separate lounge which was as big as the junior suite I had just come from with big screen TV, comfy sofas, ps4, dining area and a separate seating area with built in wall speakers to listen to your music th

Show more
Tejinder , United Kingdom
The Building Hotel
7.9 Very good
Based on 28 reviews

Hotel Independent
8.9 Excellent
Based on 788 reviews

This was my first time using agoda, and I'm extremely satisfied. The hotel looked exactly like the pictures, and I found other reviews to be true to my experience.

All the hotel staff was extremely helpful and thoughtful. I visited other cities during my trip to Italy, so I had two reservations for this hotel in Rome. When returning for my second reservation, the hotel left me a complimentary bottle of wine along with a thank you note for returning. They also left us a small treat for my birthday. As with any major city, the areas surrounding major train stations may not always be the most appealing location. However, the proximity to Termini station was extremely convenient (two minute walk), and there was also a taxi area very close by (when calling a taxi, the driver would arrive within 2min. I would definitely stay here again when in Rome.

Show more
Stephanie , United States
Artemide Hotel
9.2 Exceptional
Based on 198 reviews

food i) roof top restaurant: dinner was great! at first we were scared to try the dinner because of a review we read that food not that great in roof top restaurant.

i am glad we decided to give dinner a try.to the cooks :keep up the fantastic food! :) atmosphere in roof top was also very good. ii) breakfast: we enjoyed the wide selection & the superb service. everything went off like a well orchestrated symphony! the senior staff ( forgot to ask his name) cooly and efficiently managed the younger staff.all staff very polite and efficient> cleanliness : whole hotel was very very clean location : central location was very helpful decoration : enjoyed the very fine taste in the furniture & decoration only problem: the safe & door card gave us a bit of problem.

Ban , Malaysia

What a great stay at the Royal Suites! We got lucky and were upgraded, our room was fantastic. We were greeted by a bright flat that overlooked the shopping street outside.

The Royal is in a very convenient and safe area, and the room featured a safe (that we and the staff couldn't figure out how to operate for one full day because the instructions were wrong). The stay couldn't have been better... We skipped the hotel breakfast everyday except checkout which was a great idea. Instead of the buffet, head down to the Parliament area, an easy 300-400 meter stroll and enjoy the Parliament Cafe that has 3-4 small tables outside. The regulars here are businessmen and women, everyone is in their snazzy suits, it's a cool scene. The coffee was tops here and the pastries were warm and excellent. There is another cafe just next to the Royal, it was nice but didn't capture the experience quite like the place down by the Parliament. All in all, the Royal is excellent. Super close to the Spanish Steps, which were a great place to check in each day and enjoy a drink with the view and vibrant scene (the peddlers selling glowing flying things at the steps are particularly annoying however...). The Coloseum is in easy walking distance, This Spagna area is very good. Difficult to compare to the Pantheon area, perhaps just less crowded... The Pantheon area is very much in the center of everything, but the Royal near the steps is right in the heart of Rome as well. We definitely recommend this hotel and this area. You can book here with confidence.

8.9 Excellent
Based on 50 reviews

Extremely easy from Fiumicino : Train to Trastevere ( 25 minutes and 8 Euros ) Tram 8 stops outside the station and virually outside the hotel ( 4 minutes and 1.

5 Euros ) . All the hotel staff were very smiley and obliging . The room opened on to the garden , and had a very comfortable bed and huge power shower . The breakfast offered a good range of sweet and savoury to stock up with before a days sight seeing . The location could not be better , Trastevere is a bustling neighbourhood with a safe ambience and is packed with interesting history an well as excellent places to eat and drink. ( the pizzeria Ivo is unmissable and literally round the corner ). The Relais' location makes everything in central Rome doable on foot - and I'm no athlete !! We visit Italy two or three time a year and le Clarisse is now a top budget recommendation for us . Finally , two tips : The culinary evening walking tour of Trastevere offers a mouth-watering experience of genuine Roman cuisine . Secondly take the short train ride ( from Ostiense station ) to Ostia Antica for a rural alternative to the Forum which is much less frenetic , but no less fascinating .

It was our first time in Rome and we reached Roma Termini at almost mid night. Luckily, we managed to catch the last bus to the hotel.

It took us a while to find the hotel (actually we had already passed through as we didn't expect the hotel to be within another building). The entrance door was gigantic and luckily we notified the reception that we were expected to reach very late at night (we found out that the reception is 24hrs anyway). Through the door bell, someone opened the door for us. The hotel was on the third floor so we had to navigate a bit through the entrance, to the lift then the hotel. We didn't feel so great about the surrounding on our way, but we were fine later on. The receptionist was (not so) friendly but very helpful. He gave us the map and showed us various attractions for our 2-day itinerary. To our surprise, the room was so big for two of us. We booked a standard double room and were given a double and a single bed. The bathroom was big too. It was decorated in (I believe) classic Roma style and even the door lock was mechanical (which is common throughout Europe). The facilities were not very new but we find them acceptable. The hotel is right next to the famous shopping street Via de Corso and walkable to most attractions (nearest to Trevi fountain). Overall, we had a pleasant experience staying here. Murphy ,Ireland

A juxtaposition of dramatic historical architecture and manic modern European city, Rome is full on. Crammed with tourists mingling with elegant Roman residents (easy to tell apart as the Romans were usually slender, poised and elegantly dressed whereas the tourists were usually fat and spoke with American accents) the defining feature once away from the architecture was the traffic.

Despite appearing to be 'out of control manic' the Italians are remarkable drivers, without exception using a sliding scale of vulnerability where pedestrians are accorded absolute priority, followed by two wheeled vehicles and then four wheeled vehicles according to size. Drivers would frequently not just pull slightly over to allow a traffic splitting scooter to slip through, but even reverse or move forward to make a gap big enough. The only caveat to keeping one's sanity was that as a rider of a scooter, you had to be fast, aiming for and negotiating traffic snarl-ups with confidence. If you didn't, a horde of scooter-borne locals would thrash past on either side, looking for the front of the queue to get away from the lights first. If you've been a dispatch rider, you'll love it, if not you'll be overwhelmed, but fear not, the Italians will take care of even the most inept as long as you remember not to swerve about as you go in case an overtaking bike clips you from behind. This is my third stay in Rome and fourth time I've used two wheels in Italy and the awareness and care afforded to other road users is universal. Drivers seem to very very chilled. I think because one can ride a 125cc scooter on a car license there so car drivers HAVE a choice of whether drive or ride, and those that use a car expect the traffic jams and do not resent two wheeled riders. oh, one more thing, the black square cobbled roads around the old part ore horrible on a scooter, pummelling the rider and bike like a MIRA proving track.

More about Rome

Rome is not a city that suffers from anonymity. It’s known around the world as one of the greatest cities in history, and is a favorite among travelers who find their way to this Eternal City to take part in its famous food, culture, and history.

The city is divided into several zones, making it easy and enjoyable to explore. The Coliseum, the 8th-century BC Palatine ruins, and the Roman Forum are all located close to Colosseo metro station, a short walk from the shopping of Via del Corso. In the city center, the Pantheon, the Trevi Fountain, and the Spanish Stairs are all within a ten-minute stroll of each other. The Piazza Navona, nestled by the Tiber, is also close – just south of Vatican City.

Termini is Rome's arterial train junction. Collecting passengers from Paris and various points around Italy, it's a hub of activity 24 hours a day. Hotels near Termini provide convenient accommodation to train travelers and those taking the express rail link to Leonardo da Vinci-Fiumicino Airport. Travelers will find buses, metro links and taxis in abundance here, along with plenty of affordable dining, shopping centers and markets. Offering stunning experiences for all the senses, Rome truly is a city that must be explored at least once.

There’s much more to see and learn about Rome, and the interactive map on this page is a great way to find out where the attractions and hotels can be found in this exciting city.

Show more Saul , United Kingdom Twenty One Hotel 8 Very good Based on 159 reviews The hotel is centrally located, with many tourist spots within walking distance. The hotel is very nicely presented, and is reasonably priced for it's location. The restaurant and room service menus are incredible. We were disappointed by a few things though: 1) Even though we'd specified on the booking that we were a couple and the hotel seems to market itself towards couples, our double room consisted of two single beds pushed together. Show more Murphy ,Ireland A juxtaposition of dramatic historical architecture and manic modern European city, Rome is full on. Crammed with tourists mingling with elegant Roman residents (easy to tell apart as the Romans were usually slender, poised and elegantly dressed whereas the tourists were usually fat and spoke with American accents) the defining feature once away from the architecture was the traffic. Despite appearing to be 'out of control manic' the Italians are remarkable drivers, without exception using a sliding scale of vulnerability where pedestrians are accorded absolute priority, followed by two wheeled vehicles and then four wheeled vehicles according to size. Drivers would frequently not just pull slightly over to allow a traffic splitting scooter to slip through, but even reverse or move forward to make a gap big enough. The only caveat to keeping one's sanity was that as a rider of a scooter, you had to be fast, aiming for and negotiating traffic snarl-ups with confidence. If you didn't, a horde of scooter-borne locals would thrash past on either side, looking for the front of the queue to get away from the lights first. If you've been a dispatch rider, you'll love it, if not you'll be overwhelmed, but fear not, the Italians will take care of even the most inept as long as you remember not to swerve about as you go in case an overtaking bike clips you from behind. This is my third stay in Rome and fourth time I've used two wheels in Italy and the awareness and care afforded to other road users is universal. Drivers seem to very very chilled. I think because one can ride a 125cc scooter on a car license there so car drivers HAVE a choice of whether drive or ride, and those that use a car expect the traffic jams and do not resent two wheeled riders. oh, one more thing, the black square cobbled roads around the old part ore horrible on a scooter, pummelling the rider and bike like a MIRA proving track. It’s known around the world as one of the greatest cities in history, and is a favorite among travelers who find their way to this Eternal City to take part in its famous food, culture, and history. The city is divided into several zones, making it easy and enjoyable to explore. The Coliseum , the 8th-century BC Palatine ruins, and the Roman Forum are all located close to Colosseo metro station, a short walk from the shopping of Via del Corso. In the city center, the Pantheon, the Trevi Fountain , and the Spanish Stairs are all within a ten-minute stroll of each other. The Piazza Navona, nestled by the Tiber, is also close – just south of Vatican City. Termini is Rome's arterial train junction. Collecting passengers from Paris and various points around Italy, it's a hub of activity 24 hours a day. Hotels near Termini provide convenient accommodation to train travelers and those taking the express rail link to Leonardo da Vinci-Fiumicino Airport . Travelers will find buses, metro links and taxis in abundance here, along with plenty of affordable dining, shopping centers and markets. Offering stunning experiences for all the senses, Rome truly is a city that must be explored at least once. There’s much more to see and learn about Rome, and the interactive map on this page is a great way to find out where the attractions and hotels can be found in this exciting city.
